issues.description: Constructor parameter mismatch: The template's Main (commented example) and the UML/problem text imply single-argument constructors for animals (e.g., Seal("Clarabelle")), while the solution classes (Animal, Seal, Pig, Goat) define constructors requiring two parameters (String name, int age). This mismatch will cause compilation errors or confusion if students follow the problem/template examples but examine or run the provided solution, or conversely if automated tests (or instructors) expect single-arg constructors.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the constructor signatures consistent across artifacts. Option A (preferred to match the problem & template): change the solution to use single-argument constructors (String name) for Animal and subclasses (remove the age attribute or make it optional) so the example in Main and the UML match. Option B: update the problem statement and template Main to require/illustrate two-argument constructors (String name, int age) and document the additional 'age' attribute. Alternatively, make solution constructors overloads that accept both (String name) and (String name, int age) to preserve backward compatibility.

issues.description: Attribute mismatch / unexpected attribute: The UML and problem description specify Animal with a single attribute 'name: String', but the solution's Animal class introduces an additional attribute 'age' (int) with corresponding getter/setter and requires it in the constructor. This extra attribute is not mentioned in the problem statement or shown in the UML and thus is a structural discrepancy that may confuse students about the required attributes and constructor behavior.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the Animal attributes with the problem UML. Either remove the 'age' attribute from the solution (and adapt constructors/getters/setters accordingly) so the class only contains 'name' as specified, or update the problem statement/UML to include the 'age' attribute and document the expected constructor parameters. If keeping 'age' is desirable, update the template/Main examples to create animals with both name and age to avoid confusion.

issues.description: Constructor/signature mismatch for Animal and its subclasses across artifacts: the problem statement and template Main expect single-argument constructors that initialize only the animal's name (UML and example usage: Seal("Clarabelle"), Pig("Doodle"), Goat("Buttinsky")). The solution implementation adds an extra attribute 'age' to Animal and defines constructors for Animal, Seal, Pig, and Goat that require two parameters (String name, int age). This divergence means students following the problem/UML will implement one-argument constructors, while the solution uses two-argument constructors — creating an API/instantiation mismatch and confusion about the intended class attributes and constructor signatures.
issues.suggested_fix:
Make constructor signatures and class attributes consistent across artifacts. Two possible fixes (choose one to keep artifacts aligned):
1) Align solution to the UML/problem: remove the extra 'age' field from Animal and change Animal, Seal, Pig, and Goat constructors to accept only a single String name parameter (so example instantiations Seal("Clarabelle") in Main and the UML match the implementation). OR
2) Align problem/template to the solution: update the UML, problem text, and template Main examples to declare an 'age' attribute for Animal and show constructors taking (String name, int age), updating example instantiations accordingly. Prefer option 1 if the exercise intends to teach only the attributes shown in the UML (name only).
